text.0: Proud to be a part of this great effort! https://t.co/Aho4oAhCFt
text.1: Congratulations to #Coronavirusfacts Alliance! Led by the @factchecknet, this alliance unites 99 fact-checking organizations from all over the world in publishing, sharing, and translating facts surrounding the novel coronavirus. #ParisPeaceForum2020 #SolutionsforPeace
text.2:
Now working in English in #Ghana, #Kenya, #Nigeria, #SouthAfrica & #Zimbabwe - in partnership with @ghana_fact, @dubawaNG & @ZimFact 

And in French in Senegal
https://t.co/utTTZmNPva

Real fact-checking is not only saying what is wrong. It's also about saying what is right.
text.3: We want to know how you identify false information. Please click on the link of the survey titled 'Fact-check­ing ­in the era of ­infodemic: Examining the ­informat­ion ecosystem ­in West Africa' to fill the questionnaire.  https://t.co/631Fq2ubHm
text.4: Twitter has introduced a new feature that puts labels to identify government and state-affiliated media accounts. How will this new feature help in curbing propaganda and minimizing the spread of misinformation? Click the link to read: https://t.co/R5R8Qpi70S #DubawaChecks
text.5: A simple way to avoid spreading misinformation is to make sure to read beyond the headlines.  As a rule of thumb, the more sensational the headline, the more necessary it is to read the entire article. Read here: https://t.co/VcX3QfQtCy #DubawaChecks
text.6: What tools can journalists use to tackle misinformation? Read here: https://t.co/vUUQlFXfvO #DubawaChecks
